reviews.review_title: Not really funny - at least in today's world
reviews.content: Yes, this may be a milestone in (comedy) film making. And yes, maybe this movie was indeed perceived as funny when it came out. But looking at it now, it seems rather dull, predictive, and -- well -- not funny. After having watched it, I am not sure anymore whether it even made me smile anywhere at all. But I am positive I never had to 'laugh out loud' as some other reviewers remark.And it definitely does not represent a critical comment on war. The Civil War only serves as a background and an excuse for the 'adventure'. If you want a truly critical statement from that period, I'd recommend 'All Quiet on the Western Front' (1930) instead.However, if you are not expecting a hilarious or brilliant comedy, you might still enjoy watching the movie. But you have been warned.

reviews.review_title: The best silent picture ever made
reviews.content: Buster Keaton was the single most brilliant performer of the silent era.  He even eclipsed the extremely talented Charlie Chaplin - who has more of a following.  But, Keaton's stunts (he never used a double) and improvisational skill far exceeded anything Chaplin did while equaling Chaplin's penchant for subtlety, intimacy and humor.  Keaton's ability to play a scene with the perfect facial expression (a talent especially critical in silent pictures) also surpassed Chaplin's classic eye-rolling and mustache wiggling.  The General, which Keaton wrote and directed in addition to being the film's star, was an ambitious undertaking that showcased all of his abilities for creating empathy, tension, and zaniness in a way that - unlike virtually any other silent picture - holds up very well to most viewers even today.  Keaton's secret lies in his capacity to tap in to timeless aspects of human experience.  His style is sleek and melancholy without coming off as sentimental.  He is sophisticated and his stunts strike the viewer today as jaw-dropping and completely modern. Perhaps too modern in this film - which was a financial flop in its day. Trying to infuse the War Between the States with humor did not play well with mainstream audiences in 1927.  The General actually presented itself more effectively years later before audiences less affected by the times it depicts.  The film is flawlessly exciting, poignant, funny and technically satisfying in every respect.

reviews.review_title: Before Sullivan's Travels, there was The General.
reviews.content: I am a huge film buff, and I have great appreciation for silent films and I am always open to watching one at least once. But at the same time, I, like many people, prefer talkies to silent films and I tend to not be as entertained in terms of content. But this is one of the few exceptions. This and some of Charlie Chaplin's work are part of a small list of silent movies that I love re-watching. Let's look at the content of it: You have a periodically correct setting of the Civil War, complete with costumes, guns, resources, and trains. No expense has been spared in terms of visual entertainment, because during the 78 minute version I have, an epic chase scene between two trains unfolds, cannons are fired with cannonballs that seemingly explode on impact, and a burning bridge collapses as a train rides over it. The General is on par with many modern-day action and adventure movies in terms of eye candy that it offers. The story is solid too. You have Johnny Gray, an engineer who is denied the privilege to enlist in the Confederacy. When his train is stolen by the Union, he goes by himself to get it back and also save the girl he loves. He finds out about a surprise attack that the Union is planning, and now the pressure is on to warn his town of this attack. It's shot beautifully, not just as a silent movie but a movie in general, with many moving shots. I can think of only one other black and white movie with this much action and work put into it, and that would be Sullivan's Travels. There probably are others, but I don't think you'll find any other silent film with this much work put in.

reviews.review_title: A silent, black and white film which has some laughs. 65%
reviews.content: Despite being the major creative force in this movie (looking at Wikipedia's entry for this movie now, I seem him co-credited for roles such as director, producer, script writer and editing) Buster Keaton seems to humbly list himself in last position as far as the acting credits go, even though he is the lead actor in this movie.In this story Johnnie Gray (played by Buster) is a railway engineer (um'just' a train driver?) in America's South. It also happens to be set in the spring of 1861. For non-Americans, that date may not mean much, but no doubt most Americans would recognise it as the time when the American Civil War broke out (very early on in the movie, at the train station Johnnie pulls into, you do see two young black males carrying luggageit certainly doesn't seem like the South is a Hellhole for black peoplebut then again, you don't see anymore blacks afterwards). When his love interest Annabelle Lee (played by Marion Mack) wonders when Johnnie will enlist to fight for the South after seeing her father and brother do so, he goes to great lengths to do so, to some comedic effect. Marion makes for a feminine and attractive co-star. Keaton himself makes for physical prowess and derring do in his performance.Being an ancient comedy (i.e. being in black and white and silent to boot), I think that the humour is no doubt dated for modern audiences (or at least adult ones), but I did chuckle more than once for its duration. E.g. when Johnnie contrives to be alone with Annabelle when there are two young boys inside the mansion with them (I have no idea who those two boys were meant to beand it's also quite weird in how Johnnie and Annabelle first meetit's by no means clear they are meant to be a'courtin'). The other scene which made me chuckle was when Annabelle takes it upon herself to do some sweeping on Johnnie's train (which is called "The general", hence the title) at a rather odd moment. A few seconds after that event, there's a bizarre moment between him and her. Anyway, the humour for the most part is of the "slapstick" variety.The Wikipedia entry for this movie mentions that there are different versions of this movie which have different running times. The version that I saw was screened on ABC1 (Australia) on 06/01/2014) at 1:50 a.m. Of course I PVRd it to watch later, as well as the cult Australian movie "Stone" which preceded it. Yet to see the Australian movie thoughand I saw "The general" some weeks after I recorded itand am writing this review weeks after seeing it too. Anyway, in case the following information helps identify which version of the movie that I saw, the running time from go to whoa is 75:30 minutes length. The score features a lot of piano solo music to itI'm assuming some of the score references a funeral march piece one time, and I can definitely hear "The teddy bears' picnic" later onit's played on a constant loop for a while and later on it is used to comedic effect at an apt moment. There is one scene where the advancing army of the North gets a jaunty scorewhich makes me wonder if this was a later version of the movie."The general" has a cast of 100s at times and the cinematography is nice at timeswith shafts of light breaking into a forest. There's also a probably a good example of special effects 'magic' in one scene where you see a lightning flash. For one scene with a shot of a train on a high bridge, I did wonder if that was a model, but I could see figures moving inside of it, suggesting it was not a special effect.In favour of this movie is the good, easy to follow narrative structure and the way that the captions linger on the screen even when there is the occasional slab of text, making it less stressful to read the dialogue before it disappears.One thing of interest to note about this movie is the fact that in it, it's the South (as represented by Johnnie et.al) which is the 'hero' of the movie. This relates to my earlier query about whether the score for the advancing Union army was a later inclusion.This is my first Buster Keaton movie. As an Australian, I have to point out that having seen this movie now, I can definitely see the homage being paid to Keaton by the Australian comedian Frank Woodley (of "Lano and Woodley" famein fact, they made a sit-com together as well, "The adventures of Lano & Woodley"). I was very impressed with his 2012 sit-c0m "Woodley" and found it funny and sweet. He leans on the kind of minimalist slapstick humour utilised by Keaton in this movie. In any case, I suppose I'm saying that if you are a fan of Keaton's work, I can recommend "Woodley" at leasthis other work/TV shows are too foggy in my memory to recommend.

reviews.review_title: As an Entertainment, As a Serious Work of the Cinematic Art, this one should be required viewing! Considered to be the Zenith of Silent Film making!
reviews.content: We were introduced to Mr. Keaton's great film in an episode of "SILENTS PLEASE", televised over the ABC Television during the 1959-60 season. Buster Keaton was sort of familiar to us, but that was from his latter day work on television. Also, his sound shorts from his days at Columbia Pictures had been shown as a part of the programing on the Three Stooges show on WGN TV Channel 9, hosted by the late Bob Bell as Andy Starr, caretaker of the mythical 'Odeon' Theatre.This did very little to provide one with the knowledge of or appreciation of just exactly what Buster Keaton meant to silent screen comedy, to the development of sound comedies and just as a true pioneer of the cinematic art, period.Just for the sake of argument, we'll assume that we all are familiar with Buster's silent comedy shorts. We still may not be very appreciative of his talents not just as a great silent clown (dubbed 'The Great Stone Face' by James Agee), but also his genius as a writer, director and even as a keen eyed cinematographer.In viewing the half hour excerpted portions of The General, we get a little idea of the film. We just presume that Keaton is an actor, who is doing a movie for a studio. That what actors do, work for studios and directors.Well, once we research a little and and bone up on the subject, we discover that the work during this period was his. He thought things out and did a lot of improvising on the sets. He often worked with the thinnest script, more like an outline. The General was created that way, after Buster read the story of THE GREAT LOCOMOTIVE CHASE*, all in one sitting on on evening at home.Once you see THE GENERAL in its entirety, from beginning to end, you'll surely agree. It's available and has been so for some time. Try to see it with an audience, either at one of those 'Art Houses' or at a revival theatre, such as Chicago's Music Box. Either way, you'll enjoy and appreciate it much more.Keaton as a director, brings so many seemingly far flung elements together and creates a complex, yet straight forward gem of a film. First of all, Keaton the actor,the 'Great Stone Face', brings his own unique view of the universe to the screen,played for laughs. (and you get plenty of them!)Next we have absolutely authentic looking sets and location shooting. The large number of actors and literally army of extras (culled from local Oregon National Guardsmen) are outfitted to the tee.But perhaps the greatest technical achievement is in the overall look of the production. Keaton and his cameraman have done such a great job, particularly with the battle scenes. The battle scenes, particularly the featuring the two armies confronting each other at the bridge, have been compared to Matthew Brady Civil War Photographs.As a closing thought, we should like to relate a little anecdote that sheds a little more light on both the film and its creator. When Buster was asked by some press guy, just why he contended that THE GENERAL was a better Civil War picture than GONE WITH THE WIND, he replied, "Because it's based on a true**story!" A notion to which we heartily concur! * Yep, the very same story that Walt Disney did in the 1950's, albeit as a straight, historical drama.** The actual General, the real locomotive, is on display and may be viewed (as the Wife,the kids,my Mother-in-Law and I did several years ago) in the 'Big Shanty' Museum, 2829 Cherokee Street Northwest, Kennesaw, Georgia 30144.Telephone(770)427-2117. Tell them Red Ryan sent you.

I'm watching this in 2021 so I'm more than aware my review isn't fair but it just didn't hold up for me. There's quite a lot going on here - it is certainly comedic, but there is also plenty of action and even some romance in this American Civil War story. Keaton ("Johnnie") has been deemed more important as a railroad engineer so was rejected as a soldier - but this causes his girlfriend "Annabelle" and her family to think he is yella'! When the Yankees concoct a plan to steal his engine "The General" whilst she is travelling on it; he must use all his wits and guile to get them both back and is soon caught being enemy lines where he learns of their dastardly plan to attack. Can he get back with his gal and tell his confederates of the Unionist plans? There is something about the quality of the images - they are pretty much prefect; even when the train in rattling along a-pace. There are loads of skirmishes supporting a properly constructed, and exciting, story with plenty of drama and sometimes some quite scary bits too, all jammed into just over an hour. The version I saw had been re-scored by Carl Davis and that added immeasurably to the pace and tension - and the romance - and helped create a superb piece of cinema.

reviews.review_title: Keaton juggles comedy, suspense, historical fact in epic fashion.
reviews.content: Buster Keaton ambitious The General is a panoramic epic of immense skill. Taking a back seat to the film's central character, the locomotive, Keaton tempers his slapstick in order to make the most out of one of the biggest props in film history. When war between the North and the South breaks out Johnnie Grey rushes to enlist but is deemed too important as a train engineer for duty at the front. Girlfriend and family interpret it as cowardice though and he becomes an outcast. When a group of Union infiltrators commandeer a train to destroy supply lines by blowing up bridges Grey doggedly pursues, first on foot, then hand car, finally by locomotive.Keaton delivers an abundant amount of laughs and acrobatics with a magnificent backdrop and constantly moving train amid the splendor of the wilderness as a stage. It is as thrilling as comic with epic compositions the likes of Griffith and Lean including one of a train on a bridge that to date is unsurpassed in film history.The General was a box office failure in its day perhaps due to the challenging hybrid Keaton's comedy and an accurately portrayed life and death civil war event posed. It clearly wasn't his funniest picture but it may have well been his best. He certainly felt that way.

I have nothing against silent movies, but just because something is old, that doesn't mean that is good. Maybe this move is spectacular after the first 20 minutes, which is when I stopped watching, but I doubt it. This movie is listed as a comedy, which there isn't much of early on. As far as I can tell, the main idea of this movie is a guy has a train which gets stolen and he tries to get back. I guess if you like action scenes like that I'd recommend it. The movie is actually pretty well put together. I just don't find it that interesting. It being from the perspective of someone trying to join the confederate army doesn't really want to make me finish either.Overall, I wouldn't say that its terrible or anything, but its definitely not for me.

There's little I can say about this movie that hasn't been said better elsewhere.  Keaton is one of the great presences on the big screen and this, in addition to Steamboat Bill, Jr. and Sherlock  Jr., is the ultimate testament to his genius.  His inate ability to elicit sympathy without pandering and generate laughs from the audience are on full display in a fascinating plot with some gorgeous cinematography to boot.  Since it is a Keaton film, by definition it has breathtaking stunts.  Kino did such a wonderful job restoring this print that you would swear it was shot last year.  It is truly a sight to behold.  There's nothing like those old silver nitrate prints.  In addition, it's been said that no one has ever caught the feel of the Civil War better than Keaton did in this film.  Anyone who thinks that a movie made over 70 years ago can't be enjoyable for a reason other than nostalgia needs to see this film.  Be warned, though - once you are initiated, Buster Keaton is addictive.

Buster Keaton's acclaimed Civil War comedy, often ranked among the best films ever made, highlights all the virtues of a Keaton feature: beautiful photography; unique construction (being in this instance a mirror pair of equally inventive locomotive chases); daring stunts; and, of course, Keaton's always unexpected, perfectly timed humor. The film is also a convincing slice of antebellum Americana, with Buster stepping out of a Matthew Brady photograph to play a Confederate railroad engineer who rescues his beloved locomotive (and his almost-as-beloved girlfriend) from Union Army hijackers. The film is occasionally more thrilling than funny, but the thrills, at least, are honest: when the Rock River Bridge collapses under the Union train, nothing is faked. This is the most familiar of Keaton's classic comedies, and the frequency of revival (for a silent film) has had some adverse side effects: before the development of DVD technology most of then surviving prints were in pretty poor condition.

reviews.review_title: The General is gonna need more insurance...
reviews.content: Continuing my work on the AFI list brings me back to 1927, my second silent movie, and my first encounter with Buster Keaton. I was kind of blown away by Keaton's work in this movie. The stuff he's doing physically was really stunning to me. His mannerisms and expressions really sold the more dramatic moments and the story felt both familiar and somehow new, despite being almost 100 years old now. There was a brief bit of a pause as I realized we were following a Confederate wannabe soldier as he fought against the North to impress a girl. Not that it's a horrid story, just surprised because that's not the variation of that we often see, and given our current social climate it felt... Weird. My one and only negative would be the score. I reeeaaally didn't enjoy the music at times, it just didn't feel like it went with what was on screen. Normally, that's not a huge thing to me, but when it's a silent movie and that accompaniment goes the whole way through the film, it's harder to ignore. Even with that though, I really enjoyed this more than I expected to. Still not one I'd really recommend to casual movie watchers, but for war buffs and cinephiles? Yeah, absolutely.

reviews.review_title: Comedy And Stunts And A Great Stone Face
reviews.content: Your film journey will not be complete until you've seen a Buster Keaton comedy. The Great Stoneface was---along with Gene Kelly and Bruce Lee---one of the best athletes in the history of the movies. He was a daring stuntman who would perform his own stunts AND those of other cast members. In The General (as in so many of his great silent comedies), Keaton was the auteur who wrote, directed, produced, edited and starred as Johnnie Gray. He probably served lunch and pulled focus too.The General is the story of a man and his train...and to a lesser extent, a man and his woman. When Annabelle (Marion Mack) rejects Johnnie for not being in the Confederate Army (which is only because they tell him he's too valuable as an engineer), he goes back to his first love. Along the way, he gets caught up the Civil War anyway and does what he can to thwart the North on a critical set of railroad tracks. Hilarity frequently ensues.The movie does have some ethical problems. When Annabelle ends up on Johnnie's train, they DO make a good team, but that doesn't stop him from getting abusive with her. He practically throttles her. Plus, the movie asks us to side not only with the South during the Civil War, but with the losing side. I don't back losers! You're lucky your calm resourcefulness is so charming and likable, Buster.The General is almost a Die Hard movie where one ordinary outnumbered man battles an irresistible force and he just keeps surviving. Better yet, Keaton comes up with some of the best physical comedy of all time, performing some of the greatest stunts you'll ever see on a moving train. Those must be at least 2 reasons the American Film Institute placed it 18th on their 2007 Top 100 list after not ranking it at all in 1998. They were onto something in '07. The General overcomes any criticisms. It's dynamite!If you dug this snapshot review, check out the website I share with my wife (www.top100project.com) and go to the "Podcasts" section for our 25-minute General 'cast...and many others. Or find us on Itunes under "The Top 100 Project".

The town of Cottage Grove, Oregon, declared an official holiday to give its citizens the rare opportunity to watch the most expensive single shot in silent film take place. Thousands came out and packed the river bed of the nearby Williamette River, standing behind the six cameras recording the aging locomotive train, the 'Texas,' cross a burning bridge and cascade into the river. The spectators displayed a modicum of patience because the production crew conducted several lengthy trials running four hours late before the actual crash happened. Everyone, however, felt the wait was well worth it since the picture of the 'Texas' crashing into the river has gone down as one of the most iconic images in cinematic history-and the most costly at $40,000.The episode was the climatic point in Buster Keaton's December 1926's "The General." The movie, initially a flop, has been reassessed as one of the best silent movies, mixing romance, comedy and adventure. Keaton was especially proud of his picture, "because I took an actual happening out of the history books, and I told the story in detail too." A British film critic heralded "The General" as "perhaps the most beautiful film, with its spare, grey photography, its eye for the racy, lunging lines of the great locomotives, with their prow-like cowcatchers, with its beautifully sustained movement."
"The General" also proved pivotal in a negative way in Keaton's illustrious career. Never again would the comedian director have such independence as he did in this production. His producer, Joseph Schenck, excited about Buster's idea of recreating the April 1862 Civil War Great Locomotive Chase, gave him a $400,000 budget to spend. Unfortunately, the cost of overruns, paying a support staff of 3,000, the purchase of one train as well as the rental of two others, accidental fire damages, lawsuits and delays, rocketed the expenses almost double that was allocated. The movie, opening to some ho-hum reviews, never recouped Schenck's costs. Keaton agreed to move on to the larger MGM, thinking the rich studio would offer him larger budgeted films. Instead, the studio clamped down on the director's free-wheeling movie productions.More than just a recreation of the Great Locomotive Chase, where Union volunteers commandeered a Confederate train in Northern Georgia and damaged a good part of the 87 miles of track they rode on to escape the pursuing rebels, Keaton builds the adventure centered around his Johnnie Gray love affair with Annabelle Lee (Marion Mack). Johnnie finds himself unable to volunteer for the Southern cause because his train engineering skills are needed on the home front. Annabelle spurns his non-heroism, that is until he finds himself single-handedly frustrating the attempts of the Union soldiers to heist his train.Keaton placed himself in several perilous stunt situations, including jumping from one moving train car to another, sitting on the train's cow-catcher tossing a tie onto another one lying on the track, and sitting on a coupling rod as it goes up and down while the train is in motion. Surrounding all the thrilling train chases was a volunteer group of 500 extras from the Oregon National Guard playing both Northern and Southern soldiers. The concluding battle scenes alone cost $50,000, setting a large fire in the Oregon woods that caused a six-week delay in further filming because of the excessive smoke. The serious fighting sequences, with all its carnage, spurred writer Robert Sherwood to remark, "Someone should have told Buster Keaton that it is difficult to derive laughter from the sight of men being killed in battle."
Keaton's previous film, September 1926's "Battling Butler," received quite the opposite reception from critics and the public. The movie, adapted from a British musical play, Buster's second non-original- "Seven Chances" being his first-has him playing a rich, pampered gent whose camping trip in the mountains introduces him to a nearby rustic woman (Sally O'Neil). The two fall in love, much to the consternation of Sally's onscreen father and brother. To show he's tough, Buster tells the family he's the champion boxer Battling Butler. A series of coincidences has him confronting the real boxer, ending up with a memorable fighting sequence.So convincing were the boxing scenes in "Battling Butler," director Marin Scorsese was inspired by its realistic fight while he was researching his 1980 "Raging Bull." In a book about the movie, Scorsese claimed Keaton was "the only person who had the right attitude about boxing in the movies."
The irony of history is that today "Battling Butler," although a personal favorite of Keaton's, is now considered a minor work of his, while the unpopular "The General" is now considered a classic in silent movie comedies. Poll after poll rank "The General" one of the top movies of all time: Sight & Sound listed it as the seventh greatest movie ever made, while critic Roger Ebert included it in his Top Ten Best Movies. The American Film Institute has "The General" the 18th Best Movies in 100 Years as well as the 18th Funniest Film of All Time. And it's one of "1001 Movies You Must See Before You Die."

I have just finished watching the General. Although it is a silent film, there are many ques from the background music that demonstrate the moods that the characters can't say for themselves. It's introductory music is light with an accordion sound being the most predominant. This instrument plays well into the beginning scene and appropriately represents the bustle of life during the mid 1800s (Civil War period...just before) In the second scene of this film the protagonist Johnnie Gray learns of shots fired upon Ft. Sumter and with the strong encouragement of his girlfriend, is on his way to enlist. However, Johnnie is turned down and told he is more valuable to the South as an engineer. During this scene the music is still mostly accordion, but is slow and drawn out to represent the disappointment Johnnie feels for being unfit to serve the South. Another interesting piece of music is during the fourth scene; while Northern generals exit the train they are accompanied by a sample of quickly paced string instruments to advertise the stealth of their actions. As the music quickens the train is stolen and their plot is underway. Aside from the appropriate music accompaniments, the cinematography and the way the story was written is quite clever. There is a certain sense of sarcasm and wit put into the writing of each scene and general direction of the film. It can certainly be seen through the facial expressions and manor isms of the actors. As for the way each scene was shot and edited, I was surprised that the transition between scenes (although there aren't many) are not choppy like I had expected but rather fluid and smooth. I enjoy the contrast between the smooth changes in scenes paired with the busy/excited acting. Due to this enthusiastic style of acting, it seems as though The General has a stylized approach. I rate this silent film from 1927 a 7 out of 10. It was fairly enjoyable!

One of the best, one of the greatest movies ever, exciting, lyrical and very beautiful, with Keaton at his most likable; his role denies the reductive attempts of labeling the silent comedians' characters, the proposals of boiling them down to a recipe, to a walking cliché. These characters, each more or less typical, express and bring forth, on the higher levels of the slapstick, a resourcefulness, a relish, a haughtiness, they have a semitone of life, and their comedies are of adventures (petty or highly unusual), not of silliness. They seem odd, but they succeed.Here, with a humorous epic, the American cinema reached the ineffable. It's authentically dreamlike, an accomplished dramatic comedy, one of the earliest movies of artistic ineffable in the American cinema, it also has the national sincerity (the added honesty which only results when the deepest inspirations are honored).Keaton's role required a consummate physical shape. The character is robust and tenacious.As known, the slapstick was also a comedy of objects, they symbolize the pestering, the annoying side of general experience, like the firewood boards and logs in this movie, and therefore an initial, or occasional, or fortuitous, or transient deficit of suppleness on the human side of the interaction; but it may also give the lead an opportunity to rise, to vanquish, it may elicit his malleability, he may fend for himself, he triumphs and prevails, in which case it becomes a challenge, so the meaning of the gags with objects, with things, changes with the character's nature; in this comedy, they express his nimbleness.If in the old comedies the objects are often leveled to the stochastic anonymousness, in this one they have an unusual rank in the evening scenes at the Northern headquarters (where the engineer, hungry and shivering and anxious, slinks in). The courageous engineer masters well his locomotive.The storyline's date is 1861-1862. Its epic breath is authentic.

For such an old film, even people who don't like silent films will find themselves laughing or saying "wow". Even though Buster Keaton was his own stunt double in all of his roles, it is his role as Johnnie Gray in "The General" that stands out as one of his most daring acts.Stunts took another level in this film. The train itself, which was already way out of it's time, was risky even then. The controls, shifts, and gears were already much more complex than trains of the time, making it much harder to use and easier to screw up. However, Keaton manages not only to control the train, but ward off Union soldiers with cannons and scramble from car to car in a physically comedic sense that keeps people both laughing and on edge.I couldn't leave a review of this movie without describing my two favorite scenes out of it. First, I absolutely love the scene where Keaton must clear the way for "The General" and is forced to stand against the cow catcher with a massive wooden railroad beam. It takes great balance and strength to be able to hold the weight of the beam and maintain that position, especially when he uses the beam to knock another out of the way. Amazing!The other and most famous scene is the burning and collapse of the bridge. This scene was taken in one shot and one shot only. There was no second bridge. There was no second General. There was no fixable set. During the creation of this scene, Keaton is quoted saying he would either get this perfect or he would die with the burning train. If that's not a great rendition of a Confederate soldier, sue me. In the end, it was perfect!Overall, a great movie for all ages!

reviews.review_title: Fun, silly, creative and very silly.
reviews.content: This silent film has aged very well, the story very straightforward and this film is very adventurous and action packed. Not the most exiting film I've seen, but a pretty good experience.

reviews.review_title: A good introduction to Keaton features.
reviews.content: I do agree that "The General" should have been on the top 100 list.  Buster Keaton is the icon of the successful comedy writer/director/actors in the 1920's.  It just so happens that "The General" is a history lesson as well, and scholars at the time felt that this movie was about as authentic looking as a Matthew Brady photograph of the Civil War.  It contains the most expensive stunt done up to that time-the locomotive plunging into the river (not a model).  The movie was a labor of love from Keaton and crew and deserves to find a place in movie history long after other silents of the era have disintegrated. After viewing this movie, go on to "Our Relations" and the other fine(and perhaps funnier) movies that Keaton made, and discover the two-reelers, especially "Cops".  But this one is special.  It is right out of your history book.

reviews.review_title: The best silent movie of all time.
reviews.content: The General is the greatest silent movie ever made. While I am not a fan of silent movies, this one is an exception. The part that makes this film so great is Buster Keaton. He took a story that happened during the civil war and added humor to it. Keaton shows what life was like in the south, particually the conscription act of 1862; which is when Keaton tries to enlist but is told he is no use to the south. Then, Keaton's girlfriend refuss to talk to him until he is in uniform. When she is kidnapped, the locamotave chase begins as he sets out to find her, which is one of the funniest scenes in all of cinema. Keaton's gags and jokes make this movie enjoyabe, and I would recommend this movie over any other movie of the 1920's. I am proud to give this movie a 9/10.

According to the AFI 100 years, 100 comedies THE GENERAL is Buster greatest film. Taking place during the American Civil War, the General stars Buster Keaton as a little man who wants to be a Confederate soldier. Ironic for its time, I'm shocked that Buster made the hero character a southern confederate soldier and not a union soldier. While it must have been taken in good terms with the southern audience at its time ( along with Birth of a Nation ) I wonder how audiences in the North felt about Buster's film? Still, this is not a movie about war, it is a comedy about the little guy (Keaton) and his train. Like most of Chaplin films, he is the victim in an imperfect world. The comedy is found in Keaton's actions. This is his best comedy.
Keaton may not have the pathos of Chaplin, but his stunts and talent as a director is stunning. Awesome movie.

reviews.review_title: Great stunts and comedy for its own time
reviews.content: The story looks very much distant to what the common audience would think of. It comfortably gets away with it by inserting those comedies and stunts. This is quite a feat because for its time since it would have really need quite a genius in designing dialog-less comedy to be crack laughs. Also, even they look relatively simple particularly due to the absence of sound and lack of color, the stunts look pretty much sophisticated and highly risky. Yet then again I couldn't really enjoy silent movies so I can't really score this movie high. The acting overall is actually nice. Buster Keaton earned my respect for the equally captivating comedy and action stunts. Marion Mack did enough in covering the angle for the story.

I have seen very few silent pictures, however was quite impressed by the amount of action packed into this film. If not paying close attention to the scenes, a lot can be lost. Anyone who loves trains, as I do, will thoroughly enjoy all the antics on the locomotive. It is a very entertaining film however it seemed a bit too long.

reviews.review_title: "If you lose this war don't blame me"
reviews.content: Hearing and reading the many positive things about Buster Keaton (including a discussion of Chaplin vs. Keaton in Bertolucci's Dreamers) was some of the reasons, the others of course because his films are classics, of why I has many desires to check his films but it was until this weekend that I finally bought The General Region 4 DVD. The version of that DVD is the one with 75 minutes only and the picture and the sound of it is quite good. Anyway, I saw it last night, quite late but I knew since the beginning that this film could keep me awake easily and it did that. Keaton is Johnnie Gray, a train engineer and s because of his work that he wasn't accepted in the Confederate Army. Is fun how actually this is good since Gray is not accepted because his actual job is quite important but of course Johnny doesn't know that so he can't tell anything when his girlfriend (Marion Mack) believe that he is a coward, thanks to what her father and bother said, and left him. The film is set during the Civil War and is just fantastic how Johnnie wants to help the Confederates but mostly because external factors. First he wants to join the army because of his girl and later he began to chase the ones that stole his locomotive and ends hearing the Union strategy. Both chases are amazing and hilarious thanks to the cleverness and the skills of Johnnie but also his luck have an important role (Buster Keaton is brilliant making many impressive scenes and later Marion Mack joins him and both delivers terrific scenes). The end is also magnificent and actually Johnnie was the hero, a very lucky hero, and of course he doesn't get any credit but he finally can join the army and return with his girl (actually Annabelle Lee was with him since he rescue her from the Union in other great coincidence) Is funny to think in the consequences that can bring that choice since I don't think Johnnie can have the same luck in every battle but who knows.Conclusion: The General is a classic of the silent film era so you should watch it at least once. As I write before I saw it last night, by myself, and today I showed it to my family and they enjoyed it a lot. I loved it and even it doesn't need more recommendations I still strongly recommend you this classic picture of Buster Keaton.

My father saw this film when it was released. He was at a very impressionable age (17). He always told me Charlie Chaplin & Buster Keaton were the very best. I have to agree. I am partial to Keaton for the (sometimes) incredibly dangerous stuntwork he did. I live this film; nearly a century after it first played. Pure genius.

This movie is probably the most famous movie of Buster Keaton, i had never seen a movie with him. I'm not fond of silent movies, it bothers me most of the times. But this movie succeeded to keep me captivated and i enjoyed it. There is a lot of suspense in this movie and you ask a lot of questions during the viewing of this film like "how does he will do to save his wife?" or "is it possible to do that?". The last ten minutes with the army was a bit boring but i liked the soundtrack. Buster Keaton is a amazing actor, director and stunt performer in this film.This movie is a must see.

reviews.review_title: Great black and white classic based on a true story.
reviews.content: To be completely honest I could probably count the number of black and white films that I've watched on one hand. An extra thumb if I'm being generous. When I sat down to watch "The General" I was skeptical. A Civil War movie about a Southern railroad engineer has never been on my top list of movie plots. After giving it a sit down in front of the little big screen (my living room TV with a roku box and netflix) i was thoroughly blown away. The film, made in 1926, takes place during the start of the Civil War which had ended just sixty one years prior. When it debuted it was not received well by movie goers and critics. However, in retrospect, Keaton managed to show the human side of the Confederate cause through the story of the protagonist Johnnie Gray and his train "The General". Portraying a Southerner fighting for the Confederacy may have been off putting for movie goers from the 1920's, but was a brave choice none the less.

reviews.review_title: One of the Buster Keaton classics
reviews.content: It's a comedy set in 1861 and 1862 during the Civil War in Georgia. It's inspired by an actual 1862 capture of a Confederate train called "The General" by Union soldiers on the Western and Atlantic Railroad line between Atlanta and Chattanooga. The movie follows the train engineer's adventures in the train's capture and his efforts to retrieve it.Johnnie Gray (Buster Keaton) is the "The General" engineer based in Marietta, Georgia. The only thing he loves as much as his locomotive is his girlfriend, Annabelle Lee (Marion Mack). When the Civil War breaks out in 1861, Annabelle's father (Charles Smith) and brother (Frank Barnes) immediately volunteer. Johnnie also tries to volunteer but is rejected because his railroad work is vital. He's not told the reason, however, and Annabelle is very disappointed in him.In 1862, Annabelle takes the train to visit her wounded father; Johnnie is the engineer. While the crew is off the train for lunch, Union Captain Anderson (Glen Cavender) and his men capture "The General," including Annabelle, and head north to destroy bridges and such. The rest of the film follows Johnnie's pursuit of the captured train, his efforts to rescue Annabelle, and warn the Confederates of a surprise Union attack."The General" is one of the Buster Keaton classics. It's very visual, as silent films have to be, with a lot of slapstick humor. What's remarkable is that Keaton did not have stuntmen to perform his tricks. Silent films, with appropriate music, are a genre of their own and work well with broad comedy.

Watching the classics, everyone has one of those films that they cannot identify with, and they ask, "How do people like the movie the way they do?" For me, Buster Keaton's The General was that movie for me. It was not terrible by any stretch of the imagination, but I was not truly enthralled. I have not seen many silent films in my life, but I am a fan of Chaplin. I scratch my head in disappointment given the praise that was sung. Still, there is much to admire. Keaton did all the stunts, even the more dangerous stunts, with such acrobatic grace. The first ten minutes are great. The scene where Keaton is turned away from the Confederacy because of his "train engineer" status and the subsequent walk to his love's house is fantastic. But the rest of the film does not live up to that scene. Maybe another rewatch will be the cards?I will give Keaton the praise of authenticity. His movie was based on a train chase that took place between the Union and Confederates. He did change some parts like making the Union the bad guys because he felt people wouldn't believe the Confederates as the villains. Given Keaton's resume, everyone was excited to get production rolling. For many reasons, the film did go over budget. It was already the most expensive silent film, but the bills kept adding up. Whether it was due to expensive chase scenes, or an injury to Keaton, the money kept flowing. Upon release, the film was a box office bomb. The film did get horrible reviews but, of course, contemporary reviews have been much kinder. Still, talkies were now the part of cinematic life. Keaton took an ill-advised contract with MGM which essentially ended the career as Keaton knew it. It is sad because the man was talented. I think Chaplin is a bit better, but Keaton is no slouch based on this one film. It is disappointing I thought most of the film fell flat.Johnnie Gray (Buster Keaton) works as a train engineer for his locomotive, The General. When the Civil War begins, Johnnie is unable to enlist because of his occupation. His love of his life, Annabelle (Marion Mack), does not believe him and is ashamed. She tells him not to speak to her until he is wearing the uniform. The Union has a plan to steal the General. Once they do, Annabelle happens to be on board. Johnnie now makes it his duty to rescue his sweetheart.Keaton himself is the best part of the movie. Maybe not his directing, but his actual performance. He does not create scenes around gags, but rather the opposite. Some are funny, some are not. He does try his best. I was surprised how much action the film had. He did all the stunts and did them with such grace. I do want to see his earlier body of work. Marion Mack is a decent love interest for Keaton, but nothing is memorable about her performance.I really wanted to like The General. The story fell apart pretty quickly. Keaton is the only glue that holds the movie together, and that glue is barely holding. Like I said, everyone has a classic film they are less fond of than others. This, sadly, happens to be mine. This was the movie that derailed Keaton's career and it really is a shame to see a cinematic giant fall out like that. This is not a complete failure, but only if it had more effective laughs/gags/.My Grade: C.

reviews.review_title: A summary of all things great and gloomy of the Civil War.
reviews.content: Buster Keaton's silent epic The General is more than just one of the best silent films ever made, it is also a wonderful tribute and nostalgic look back to a fascinating era in this country when the states were divided and each side knew exactly what they wanted. In this instance, Keaton plays Johnnie Gray, a humble and simple-minded engineer whose life is occupied by two things, his train and his girl. In only a matter of minutes, he loses both and there is nothing left to do but start running and track them down.This is not necessarily a new concept for Keaton, but his ability to perform different stunts all the while entertaining the audience as well as moving the story along. Indeed, the plot moves as quickly and fluidly as the trains in the story, which seem almost a metaphor for the lifestyle most were living at a time when war was upon all the nation. As for the stunts, Keaton has some very good ones as well as other visual tricks he sneaks in that happen almost so suddenly, it's as if he didn't want you to notice them on their own. Nevertheless, they are there and multiple viewings may be necessary to capture all the richness of this story. And with Buster Keaton playing the lead, we empathize with him every step of the way. Despite his stone face, this only enhances the comedic steps of each pun and we like him even more. For anyone who loves history or the movies or both, The General is a splendid ride and one that should be taken more often than not.

reviews.review_title: A Thoroughly Entertaining Silent Era Film
reviews.content: Although The General is widely considered a comedic masterpiece amongst critics, I found most of the slapstick humor to fall flat and sometimes completely out of place. The film had a much more action genre feel than of a comedy. It fails to keep a consistent comedic tone which I feel ultimately hurt the overall film. Buster Keaton's character seems to resemble more of a Clumsy Rambo than a comic hero.I also found Buster Keaton to be somewhat irritating. His dead pan expression made his performance feel stiff. Aside from his facial expressions, the rest of his performance was quite entertaining. Although The General fails comically, the overall film is entertaining. I would recommend this film to anyone wanting to broaden their horizons with film, but I would advise that it is somewhat forgettable.

The General is Buster Keaton's big-budget blockbuster. Well, big-budget by 1920s standards anyway, featuring the most expensive stunt of the silent era. And in truth it really was no blockbuster upon its initial release, faring rather badly at the box office and with the critics. Yet more than eighty years later the film is considered an all-time classic. The General is undoubtedly one of the benchmark films of its era. For anyone seeking an introduction to the silent era there could be few better places to start than with this film.The General has a very simple story which begins in the South in 1861. Keaton plays Johnny Gray, a train engineer who loves two things. There's his girl, Annabelle Lee. And his locomotive, the General. Of course a movie set in the South in 1861 is going to be a Civil War story. When the war breaks out Johnny tries to enlist in the Confederate army but is rejected as he is more valuable to the South as an engineer. Only nobody bothers to tell him why he has been rejected. And Annabelle, thinking him to be a coward unwilling to enlist, says she will have nothing to do with him until he is in uniform. Which leads to one of the film's most famous shots with brokenhearted Johnny, lost in his thoughts of Annabelle, going up and down on the coupling rods of his engine as it sets into motion.A year passes, the war rages, and Johnny still works as an engineer. And then Union spies steal his train, his General. And there is one prisoner on board when the spies make off with Johnny's beloved General, Johnny's beloved Annabelle. Initially Johnny doesn't know there's a prisoner. He doesn't even really know who took his train or why. He just knows he's got to get it back. And so the great chase begins, first on foot, soon on handcar and bicycle, and eventually on another locomotive, the Texas. Along the way there are plenty of mishaps, misunderstandings and misadventures, some great comedic moments. But this is not a straight comedy by any means, it is also a great action film as well. It all comes together quite wonderfully, brilliantly conceived and brilliantly executed throughout by the superb Keaton.In addition to being a brilliant actor and director Keaton may well be as talented a stunt man as films have ever known. In this film he makes it all look so easy. It's only afterwards when you think back on some of the things you've just seen him do that you realize how dangerous some of these stunts really were. Keaton was willing to put himself into positions where he was one slip away from certain doom. He did things no modern movie star would ever be allowed to do. The stunts had to be precise and they were. And for the gags to work Keaton's timing had to be impeccable and it was. There is not nearly as much of a slapstick feel to this film as there is in so many other silents. This film's laughs are much more subtle but no less effective. And moviegoers who know nothing but the talkies will find they don't even miss the words. Keaton can say as much with just a simple look as today's actors can with a full page of dialogue. No wild exaggerations or outlandish gestures necessary, Keaton stays composed and still gets his point across. The General showcases a great filmmaker at the height of his powers. It is of an era which has been largely forgotten but this landmark film endures.

The age old debate of whether you are a Charlie Chaplin or Buster Keaton fan, is still a popular discussion among movie fans, critics and students. For me I choose Keaton. No doubt Chaplin is funny, I just choose Keaton because in addition to his humor he is also doing amazingly, dangerous stunts. Growing up on Jackie Chan movies I've always found live stunts exciting and the stunts in The General are very compatible to today. These stunts add such suspense to the movie that you almost forget that it's a silent film, putting this film right up there with today's Hollywood blockbusters. Given the time period compared to today's safety and medical advancements, it's purely amazing that similar stunts were even considered in 1926 and thus I give it an 8 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: The first transcontinental railroad in the USA, linking the east and the west, opened on March 10th, 1869
reviews.content: The winner of my favorite 1926 film comes in the guise of The General (1926). It highlights Buster Keaton at his best. The majority of the film takes part on top of a train. Yes, on top of a train, not just in a train, but on top of it with Buster running all over the place. When I see films on trains they usually look fantastic and this one does not disappoint.Jackie Chan always said that one of his favorite Hollywood stars was Buster Keaton, and you can see why in this film. Buster pulls off the same kind of comedic moves that Jackie would incorporate into his agile performances. This movie contains some exciting stuff! This is another one of those high-speed, exciting films found in that sub-genre called the chase film, which is one of my favorite sub-genres.This is outstanding and even the love story part of the film is funny. In one scene the bad guys are chasing Buster all over the train and once he dispatches them the girl grabs a broom and starts sweeping, thus triggering another humorous response from Buster. I loved that scene. This film would get an A+ out of me if they hadn't used a bad shot of her face through a key hole in a door involving a table cloth. They should have avoided that. A great film though.9.5 (A MyGrade) = 9 IMDB.

reviews.review_title: Buster Keaton perfectly balanced romance, action and comedy in his most admired film and personal favorite, a Civil War story about an engineer and his eponymous locomotive.
reviews.content: The General has all the sweet earnestness in the world. It is about trains, frontier America, flower-faced girls. The story is about a Confederate train driver (Buster Keaton) who gets his train and his girl back when they are stolen by Union soldiers.The film is slow-starting, then hilarious action comedy, often voted one of the best films ever made. Its sequences of sight gags, each topping the one before, is an incredible joy to behold. The film, however, was a box-office disaster on its original release. The story is based on an actual incident of the Civil War, treated more seriously in The Great Locomotive Chase.

On my list of classic films to see in 2006, Buster Keaton's 'The General' was one of the top three. I had always heard great things about this film, so I went into my first viewing with quite some expectation- and I found 'The General' to be every bit the classic it is known as. Keaton's genius shaped a terrific, original feature-length comedy film that has stood the test of time brilliantly.In this Civil-War masterpiece, 'The Great Stone Face' Keaton's Johnny Gray is an engineer who cherishes but two things- his locomotive ('The General, hence the name of the picture) and his beautiful, but rather dumb girl, Annabelle Lee. The premise is simple yet inspired: Johnny is turned down for active service in the Civil War because he is deemed to be more valuable as an engineer. Annabelle isn't too impressed- she won't speak to him again unless he enlists. Down-hearted yet forever blank-faced Keaton finds himself soon battling to retain both his loves, when The General is stolen by Union spies with Annabelle on board. Ladies and gentleman, the chase is on! A lot of silent comedy isn't well-received today, yet the likes of Keaton and his contemporary Charlie Chaplin are still viewed as legends of the genre. I think it is because they both shaped out defining, lovable characters for themselves- Charlie's 'Little Tramp' and Keaton's embattled working-man. Like Charlie's tramp, Keaton's Johnny is an observer, misplaced in a world of mechanization and economy. Yet he's the unseen contributer who manages to influence society unknowingly and often single-handedly.This is filled with the terrific sight gags Keaton was famous for, with many gags involving him and Marion Mack (who plays Annabelle)as the mismatched couple. The fast-pacing Keaton maintains throughout is amazing-'The General' definitely proves silent films are not sleep-inducing! Keaton's little man is always challenged by machinery, so he has to keep up with it or fall behind. The amazing stunts and army sequences could rival any modern film for genius and sheer artistry. It looks beautiful- the cinematography is superb. 'The General' was apparently one of the most expensive silent films ever made, largely due to one terrific shot (I won't spoil it for you) that is the product of all Johnny's toil and effort.A film with a Civil-War setting was daring for Keaton to make at this time, with Griffith's 'The Birth Of A Nation'(1915) being successful a decade earlier yet still VERY controversial. Adding comedy to the tragedy of war seemed like a sure-fire way to make a flop in the 20's, and Keaton's film wasn't very well received for decades. It now regularly features in greatest film lists and is often at the top of greatest silent film lists- finally getting the recognition it deserves.Bravo, Keaton!10/10.

"The General" is considered by many to be the best comedy of the silent film era. That's quite a reputation to live up to, but having now seen it I can readily see why it's thought of so highly, and say that it doesn't disappoint in the least. It's a totally one-of-a-kind film, and completely pleasurable and engrossing from start to finish. It's been said that it isn't properly a comedy, but I think once one starts watching it doesn't matter: the simple and human but methodical and intricate story of how Buster sets out singlehandedly to rescue the train and woman he loves is so absorbing that when the comedy (which is as musically times as the rest of the film and all hits home) stop we are too busy being thrilled by the stunts, coincidences, and stunning set pieces to notice, and when these stop we are too busy laughing to care.Perhaps eighty per cent of "The General's" hundred or so minutes consist of one train chasing after another on the tracks. It's no surprise this brings unity, but it's a unique achievement for Buster that even within that potentially monotonous framework nothing becomes repetitious and the tension never ceases. The film-making itself and the timing in these hugely complicated shots involving steam trains narrowly missing each other and countless other obstructions is so precise and flawless that it would be possible simply to ignore the rest of the film and marvel at that for the running time if one felt like it.Buster Keaton's brilliantly off-kilter and eccentric way of viewing the world -- creating hilarious gags both social and mechanical that seem woven from exactly the same cloth -- comes together with a relatable and admirable quest story with natural and highly sympathetic human interest, and some of the most technically pin-perfect execution imaginable to create an extraordinary mix of comedy and thrill that we can invest in too. It's definitely among the most memorable films I've ever seen.

reviews.review_title: Enjoyable Civil War action film, great stunts still hold up well
reviews.content: This is an immensely enjoyable film that was far ahead of it's time when first released. The physical stunts still impress and Buster Keaton gives a memorable performance. His athletic ability rivals and possibly exceeds Chaplin. The film is also remarkably restrained for a silent film and Keaton never overacts to attract our sympathy. 'The General' is basically a straight Civil War action film with comedic elements. The humor arises naturally from the complicated stunts performed. The film is a trifle overlong and the climactic (MINOR SPOILERS) battle takes away the focus from Keaton. Still highly recommended.Overall 8/10

reviews.review_title: Johnnie Gray is the ancestor of Charlie Chaplin
reviews.content: Outstanding performance by Buster Keaton. What a silent comedy! What a character is this train engineer! Beautiful! This action-adventure-comedy is smooth and light fight with trains. But obviously, those kind of trains of the first ones - those that work with firewood and a flexible 'driver'.Our main character, very tenacious, wants his love. He has his first one, the train, and now he wants Annabelle Lee. He does everything, from the beginning till the end to achieve her attention. An attention obtained because of an uniform. Yes, that is true, but only because those times were like that.But forget about that love - cheap kisses and looks - because in here the story is about these bloody trains and how they chase each other. Interestingly enough, for 1926 this 67 minutes are 'marvelous'! There is more text than The Kid (1921) or City Lights (1931), and even more comedy and captivation. Yes, it is true that is all about those trains, but the story goes on the rails with a linear perspective.

The weekday evening performance was sold out, the cinema full, and the faces in the audience predominantly young: the classics in the National Film Theatre's Buster Keaton season, thanks to widespread media coverage, had drawn interest from a general public beyond existing fans of the silent screen, and I'd hazard a guess that a fair number of those seated around me were coming to Keaton for the first time. My own Damascene conversion from mild scepticism to ardent advocacy having taken place all of a whole week earlier -- in the moment of laying eyes on his first self-directed short, 'The High Sign', to be precise -- I naturally fell prey to all the superiority of the old hand :-) But the audience reaction was a fascinating transition, and a true homage to the film. For as they began to be drawn in, they *stopped laughing*.Silent comedy, and Keaton's in particular, suffers from the slapstick label; the preconception is of custard-pies and prat-falls, of silly hats and floppy shoes, and exaggerated facial mugging. The people who had come to see "The General" had come with the expectation of pantomime humour and unkind gags, and in the opening scenes there were loud laughs at everything that could by any stretch be interpreted as 'funny'. Buster's character was clearly the butt and not the hero of the piece.The change was gradual. I was too much involved by the story myself to pinpoint the moment when the laughter turned to gasps, and then to cheers, as Keaton's dogged Johnnie Gray battled through one frustration or death-defying danger after another with grace, skill and the occasional gift of unprompted good luck. Long before the climactic stunt -- which drew forth a many-throated cry, including my own -- they were on his side, laughing with him and not at him, with affection for his awkwardness, with admiration for his achievements, and with applause for his ingenuity. By the final romantic coda, in which Johnnie finds a typically resourceful solution to the problem of embracing his girl and acknowledging his new responsibilities at the same time, the self-conscious guffaws of the opening scenes were gone as if they had never been: the roar of approbation almost raised the roof.For "The General" is nearly as much a straight adventure or tale of crossed lovers as it is a comedy; I'd seen flickering railway-related snippets of it myself previously, as a 'train film', which was about as misleading out of context. It's not the perfect melding of story and humour which I still dream to find in some film of Keaton's as yet unseen -- it spends too much of its length for my taste in chase sequences, with consequent repetition of this material (running out of wood, detaching vehicles, obstacles on the rails, diverting tracks), while conversely the battle scenes at the end seem somewhat unrelated -- but it caught me out of myself with all the thrills of a great drama and the tenderness of a wry romance.For long periods it is in fact more gripping than funny, and this is no loss. The watchers were caught up beyond laughter, into an exhilaration of engagement that had eyes sparkling with a buzz of applause. No need for condescension for the slapstick crudities of the good old days: the film has all the resource and surreality that are Keaton's trademark... and if Buster never cracks a grin then his audience most assuredly do.

I set out a couple of years back to see if I could watch everything on the top 250. There have been movies on the list I was very underwhelmed by, and there have been those I have loved. This is a movie that I would have never just watched had I not been going through the list, but it is now one of my favorite movies. I had seen a few couple of silent films before seeing this, mostly Charlie Chaplin, but this introduced me to Buster Keaton and it instantly made me want to go find as many of his old films as I could. While I liked a great many of them, The General still stands above them all. I have shown this movie to friends and family who have never watched silent films and, despite their reservations, they have all loved it. It takes a while for the movie to get going, but once it does the stunts are amazing considering Buster performed them all. Highly recommend.

During his day The General was both a critical and box office failure. Today however it is viewed as classic cinema and one of the greatest films of it's era. The story revolves around the life of a train engineer (played byKeaton) who is moved by his fellow Southerners to fight against the Union. Sadly he's rejected by the local militia, nut with his trusty locomotive "The General", Buster finds away to help the cause! He also has to balance outthe two loves in his life, his fiancée and "The General". Can he find truelove and save the day?I found this film to be an outstanding work of art. The stunt andsecondary direction by Buster Keaton is outstanding. His work was veryinnovative and ahead of it's time. He risked his safety on many occasionsand the bridge stunt was the most expensive set piece during the silent era.Much maligned in it's day but today The General is looked upon as a truecinematic treasure.Highly recommended for silent movie fans and film history buffs.A+

reviews.content: I appreciate that Buster Keaton did his own stunts and how dangerous they are I also appreciate how difficult the sequences involving trains must have been to pull off. How this movie could have been left out of the top 100 flicks of all time I will never know. I remember Keaton as a grumpy old man in the cinema of the 50's and 60's. It was only later when in college film school that I recogized his true genius. The General was one of the first silent movies that I was ever able to sit though long enough to fully appreciate the medium. It had everything, drama, comedy, action, romance. It was also pretty much true to the real event also. My favorite part is when Keaton has rescued the train and his girlfriend and they are escaping the federal troops in full pursuit. This is Keaton's masterpiece always.

reviews.content: Everything about Buster Keaton's "The General" is perfect. It is completely flawless. The sets, the timing and the comedy itself are all world class. I have seen only 4 perfect films and they are: The General, Raging Bull, Aguirre, the Wrath of God, and Citizen Kane. Out of those 4 The General is my favorite, my favorite of all films. My very favorite movie

reviews.review_title: Despite being nearly a century old, it still manages to raise a laugh
reviews.content:
The General is probably Buster Keaton's best known film, but it's probably the case that most people who have heard of it nowadays have only seen clips from it. Silent black-and-white movies don't have the audience they once had, with home media and online streaming sales probably limited to aficionados of cinema and film students. But if you can cope with the idea of a silent comedy, then The General is a good place to start: despite being nearly a century old, it still manages to raise a laugh.
Keaton once said that The General is the film he was proudest of, because it is based on a true story and he tells it in detail. It is indeed based on actual events, specifically the theft of a train by the Union Army during the Civil War, and the screenplay - partly written by Keaton and his co-director Clyde Bruckman - works as a solid piece of storytelling. It sees railway engineer Johnnie Gray (Keaton) setting out to retrieve his beloved train (the titular General) from the Union agents who stole it, and culminates in a climactic battle and Johnnie regaining the love of his fiancé Annabelle Lee after she earlier spurns him when she thinks he has refused to sign up for the army. Interestingly, Keaton didn't think that audiences would accept Confederates as villains, so the Johnnie Gray is a Southerner who tries and fails to enlist in the Confederate army before thwarting the Union Army almost single-handedly; this now dates the film more than anything else. Notably, the film also falls into the very small handful of films that might be described as "war comedies" and - unusually - it includes comic sequences in which people die.
But whilst the plot and the characterisation is well thought out, the main attraction is of course Keaton the actor, clowning his deadpan way through the film and performing stunts that still astonish today. It's pure slapstick, mostly based around one of the trains that feature heavily, and Keaton performs with such effortless choreography that it can't help impress: that in itself doesn't make it funny, and yet despite its age it remains one of those rare silent comedies that retains its power to make the audience laugh, not just admire the physicality of its central performance.
The General is also remarkably well made, acting as the best showcase there is of Keaton's (and Bruckman's) skills as a director. Shot largely on location and using real trains, it's an impressive piece of film making. The dynamic camera work of cinematographers Bert Haines and Devereaux Jennings, who mount cameras on moving trains and include a wide variety of impressive shots, is ahead of its time as indeed is Keaton's editing. The crash of the Texas looks particularly good (probably because it was achieved by buying and crashing a real train!), as does the well-staged battle between the Union and the Confederate Armies at the climax of the film. Less obviously, the sets and costumes both reflect the detailed research into the period that Keaton carried out.
Mention should also be made of Marion Mack, who gives an excellent performance as Annabelle Lee, playing straight-woman to Keaton for large chunks of the movie. She's especially good as his foil during the sequence in which Johnnie rescues Annabelle, as he gets hit by a lightening-struck tree and surprised by a bear, and Annabelle steps in a bear-trap. Keaton makes an unlikely romantic lead, but somehow his hangdog expression makes him rather endearing.
The General is the sort of film that cinephiles like to wax lyrical about and which most people born in the last century have never seen. But it's celebrated amongst film fans for many reasons, but the most compelling one is that it is still really funny.

I'm a big fan of Chaplin and Laurel & Hardy and the Marx Brothers, but I was never a fan of Buster Keaton. Among my favorite directors are, besides Chaplin, also Hitchcock, Wilder, Kubrick, Fellini, Wise and many more. I watched "The General" because of the many good reviews and I am - as I expected - very disappointed. The plot is as follows (don't even call it a spoiler because it's so simple): The evil Yankees steal Buster's train and his girl. He gets both back and thwarts an insidious attack of the Yankees on the heroic and good Southerners. The end. I don't want to go into the political incorrectness of the film (pro slavery), it's only about artistic aspects. The film was produced with a relatively large technical effort and contains action scenes that are remarkable (I wonder, however, if Buster disposed of the train that was sunk in the river properly). The film is absolutely not funny and hardly entertaining. Many of the "gags" seem rather embarrassing and far-fetched, I laughed even less than Buster himself (a.k.a. as the man who never laughed). All in all, this film has confirmed that Buster Keaton is immensely overrated as an artist. On a scale of 0 to 10, Charlie Chaplin gets 10 points, and Buster 1 point. Amazing that Charlie gave his colleague a small role for his late work Limelight, perhaps out of pity for his suffering colleague whose career ended in a financial fiasco.

In what is said to be his landmark film, Buster Keaton plays Johnnie Gray, a train engineer in Tennessee in 1861. When war breaks out, he decides to enlist but is turned down because he is more valuable as an engineer. His girlfriend's father and brother believe him to be too afraid to enlist, and his girlfriend refuses to speak to him until he is in uniform. A year later, Gray is engineering his train, the General, which is then stolen by Northern spies and used to halt supplies to the South. Gray pursues the train by handcar, bicycle, and engine car, then after rescuing his girlfriend, who was on the train, the tables are reversed as the spies chase him Gray, on the General. Pretty innovative comedy, with great stuntwork by Keaton ( including knocking away the railroad tie with another ), and a good feeling all around. Keaton turns in an absolutely great performance with a great showing of slapstick, sympathy, and and romance. Rating 10.

I yield to no one in my appreciation of Buster, but I think this is one of his more boring films. I don't understand why everyone thinks it's so great; I much prefer "Sherlock Jr.," "The Navigator", and "Steamboat Bill, Jr." Although the movie definitely has moments I like, the storyline moves slowly,  it seems like the long shots of trains are endless, and the supporting characters aren't developed as well as they are in some of his other films. Also, I can't stand the way Buster took a true-life tale about the Union army and changed it to be about Confederates. (His explanation was that audiences would naturally root for the underdog, but it's kind of hard for me to be on the side of someone who is fighting to keep slavery legal.)

Buster Keaton's silent comedy classic "The General" (1926) is a film that went ignored for a long time. It wasn't until the 1960s that film buffs and film critics really started to appreciate it. Up to that point, it was always thought of as "just another one of those old Buster Keaton comedies". Nowadays, the film is obviously held in high regard and considered to be a classic.What is the story about? Well, it's about a train engineer named Johnnie Gray who loves his train (called The General) and his girlfriend named Annabelle. He tries to enlist for the Confederate army but his services are not accepted because he's thought to be important as a train engineer. Annabelle doesn't believe him and thinks he's a coward. But then one day, Union spies steal his train, and Johnnie sets out to get it back and pursues the train through enemy lines. He must rescue both of his loves.What makes this film so great, then? Well, it's in my own personal top 10 films of all time, and I would say I enjoy it mostly because of three things: 1) it's wildly funny, 2) endlessly entertaining, and 3) very inventive (especially for its time). And of course, Buster Keaton's stunts are superb, as they always are. There are also quite a few iconic shots in the film that have always stayed in my mind. The train on the bridge above the river... Or the shot of Buster sitting at the front of the moving train and knocking out one wood log with another wood log and thus, preventing the train from stopping. So awesome.10/10, a masterpiece. Highly recommended to anyone who's interested in film. The Blu-ray quality is excellent as well.
